verses.text: Now Moses was tending the flock of Jethro his father-in-law, the priest of Midian, and he led the flock to the far side of the wilderness, and came to the mountain of God, to Horeb.
verses.comment: Moses, who would become the lawgiver, is introduced in a humble setting as a shepherd. The 'mountain of God,' later known as Sinai, becomes a central place of divine revelation and covenant. The reference to Jethro as priest subtly foreshadows the perpetual role of priesthood as mediators between God and His people.

verses.text: And the angel of the LORD appeared to him in a flame of fire out of the midst of a bush. He looked, and behold, the bush was burning with fire, yet the bush was not consumed.
verses.comment: The 'angel of the LORD' sometimes acts as God's own presence in the Old Testament. The fire that does not consume prefigures God's holiness—powerful, yet merciful. Early Christians saw manifestations like these as anticipating the Incarnation: God coming among men in a way that does not destroy, but sanctifies.

verses.text: And Moses said, 'I will turn aside and see this marvelous sight, why the bush is not burned up.'
verses.comment: Moses' willingness to investigate the mystery shows an openness to divine revelation, which is essential for any vocation or calling from God.

verses.text: When the LORD saw that he turned aside to look, God called to him out of the bush, 'Moses, Moses!' And he said, 'Here I am.'
verses.comment: God's double calling of Moses' name indicates intimacy and urgency. Throughout salvation history, God calls individuals by name to serve His purposes, a theme fulfilled in Jesus' personal calling of His disciples.

verses.text: Then he said, 'Do not come closer; take off your sandals from your feet, for the place on which you are standing is holy ground.'
verses.comment: Removal of sandals is a sign of reverence. God's presence sanctifies physical places, just as sanctified spaces play a role in biblical worship and tradition.

verses.text: And he said, 'I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.' And Moses hid his face, for he was afraid to look at God.
verses.comment: God identifies Himself with the patriarchs, recalling His fidelity. This is quoted by Jesus in the Gospels to affirm the resurrection and ongoing relationship of the living God with His people.

verses.text: Then the LORD said, 'I have surely seen the affliction of my people who are in Egypt, and have heard their cry because of their taskmasters; I know their sufferings.'
verses.comment: God's intimate knowledge of His people's suffering shows His compassion and faithfulness. This anticipates the ultimate act of solidarity when the Word becomes flesh to save humanity.

verses.text: So I have come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians, and to bring them up from that land to a good and spacious land, a land flowing with milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Amorite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite.
verses.comment: God's promise to 'come down' and deliver mirrors the Incarnation, where God comes into the world for salvation. The idea of a prepared, fruitful land points toward the ultimate inheritance for God’s people.

verses.text: And now, behold, the cry of the children of Israel has come to me, and I have seen how harshly the Egyptians oppress them.
verses.comment: God's attentiveness to prayer and suffering shows His justice and care, mirrored in Christian beliefs about intercession and mercy.

verses.text: Come, and I will send you to Pharaoh, so that you may bring my people, the children of Israel, out of Egypt.'
verses.comment: The sending of Moses prefigures God sending individuals for deliverance—ultimately fulfilled in Christ’s sending by the Father for the world's salvation.

verses.text: But Moses said to God, 'Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh, and that I should bring the children of Israel out of Egypt?'
verses.comment: Moses' humility and sense of inadequacy are a hallmark of many biblical figures called by God. God's choice often rests not on human capability, but on divine appointment and grace.

verses.text: And he said, 'Certainly I will be with you, and this will be the sign to you that I have sent you: when you have brought the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain.'
verses.comment: God promises His presence with Moses—a theme fulfilled perfectly in the enduring presence of God with His people. The promise of worship on this mountain constitutes both a physical and spiritual gathering.

verses.text: Then Moses said to God, 'If I come to the children of Israel and say to them, "The God of your fathers has sent me to you," and they ask me, "What is his name?" what shall I say to them?'
verses.comment: Knowing God's name symbolizes deeper relationship. Here Moses seeks assurance not only for himself but for the people, echoing humanity’s quest to know the Divine intimately.

verses.text: God said to Moses, 'I AM WHO I AM.' And he said, 'Say this to the children of Israel: "I AM has sent me to you."'
verses.comment: 'I AM WHO I AM' expresses God's absolute, self-existent being. Jesus applies this name to himself in John 8:58, a direct claim to divinity recognized by His hearers. This verse underscores the unity between Old and New Testament revelation.

verses.text: God also said to Moses, 'Say this to the children of Israel: "The LORD, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has sent me to you." This is my name forever, and this is how I am to be remembered for all generations.'
verses.comment: God’s covenantal identity is tied to His ongoing relationship with His people down through generations. The invocation of the patriarchs connects worship through time, underlining that God is the God of the living.

verses.text: 'Go and gather the elders of Israel together and say to them, "The LORD, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob, has appeared to me, saying: I have watched over you and have seen what has been done to you in Egypt,"'
verses.comment: Communication is directed first to the elders, pointing to the importance of structure, hierarchy, and order in God’s people for authentic transmission of the faith.

verses.text: 'and I have promised that I will bring you up out of the affliction of Egypt to the land of the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Amorite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite, to a land flowing with milk and honey.'
verses.comment: Repeating the promise signifies the certainty and abundance of God’s blessing, foreshadowing the spiritual inheritance for all believers.

verses.text: They will listen to your voice, and you and the elders of Israel shall go to the king of Egypt and say to him, 'The LORD, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us. So now, please let us go a three days' journey into the wilderness, that we may sacrifice to the LORD our God.'
verses.comment: Gathering together for sacrifice is a communal act of worship and obedience—a pattern that holds true for God's people throughout salvation history.

verses.text: But I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go unless compelled by a mighty hand.
verses.comment: Pharaoh's resistance demonstrates the contest between human will and divine authority, showing that God’s plan is accomplished not merely by human means but by God’s power.

verses.text: So I will stretch out my hand and strike Egypt with all the wonders that I will do in its midst. After that, he will let you go.
verses.comment: The 'wonders' or signs reveal God’s sovereignty over nations and nature, foreshadowing the miracles later performed by Christ and His apostles.

verses.text: And I will make the Egyptians favorably disposed toward this people, so that when you go, you will not leave empty-handed.
verses.comment: God's justice includes restitution; Israel will not only be freed but also enriched—a picture of grace beyond mere liberation.

verses.text: Every woman shall ask of her neighbor, and of any woman living in her house, for articles of silver and gold, and for clothing. You will put them on your sons and your daughters, so you will plunder the Egyptians.'
verses.comment: The plundering of Egypt fulfills God’s promise and symbolizes the victory of God's people over oppression. The detail of women leading this act highlights the active role of all members of the faith community in receiving God's promises.
